subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Foreign sounds (was Re: Maps in Quikscript)
msgSnippet: Why /should/ quikscript be adapatable to other languages?  That would require it to have symbols for phonemes which English doesn t have.  The problem with TO
messageBody:
Why /should/ quikscript be adapatable to other languages? That would
require it to have symbols for phonemes which English doesn't have. The
problem with TO is that is doesn't meet English's phoneme needs whereas
QS does. As English phonemes change in the future, then QS will have to
adapt to those changes. Otherwise, in a few centuries, our spelling
would once again not match the pronunciation.

Read, of course, was not concerned with devising an alphabet that could
be adapted to other languages. The fact that the Roman alphabet is used
so widely is, I assume, a historical artifact of the Roman empire. But
grafting the Roman alphabet onto languages too divergent from Latin did
not work all that well, with English being, perhaps, the prime example.

I would expect that the problem in using QS for other languages would be
the vowels. The consonants from one European language to another are
like lighthouses of stability in the stormy sea of vowel fluidity. So
the consonants could be used fairly easily across the European languages
that I have some familiarity with even though there are differences in
pronunciation. The vowels are a different matter. Additional vowels
could be added to QS to represent sounds from other languages. But why
should Spanish or German want to use QS when their written languages are
quite phonemic already using the Roman alphabet? I don't see what
purpose it would serve other than trying to decrease the number of
alphabets in use in the world. Is anyone suggesting the Greeks or
Russians should adopt the Roman alphabet to make things easier for other
people to learn how to write in those languages?

Regarding the pronunciations of words, including the names of cities in
foreign countries, I believe they should be written in QS in the closest
manner to the pronunciation of the natives and then pronounced according
to that spelling. In other words, we are not trying to get English
speakers to employ phonemes that don't exist in English since that is
not likely to work any more than expecting Germans to pronounce "th" in
a word is likely to work.

A mistake that has been made in TO is bringing foreign words into
English, continuing to spell them as they were spelled in the foreign
language, but pronouncing them differently. Example: "foyer," which
many people are now pronouncing just the way it looks rather than with
the long-a sound it should have at the end.

Cheers,

Paige

Benct Philip Jonsson wrote:
tinyallen wrote:

> > How about using the actual native's name, as well as
> > pronunciation? For example, what we Americans call
> > Munich is (AFAIK) "Myuunchen" to a local German
> > speaker. I have had international friends who wondered
> > why Americans (and the British) couldn't say the names
> > of a few cities.
>

> Which opens the subject that QS is for better or worse quite
> tightly bound to the particular sound inventory, especially
> vowel inventory, of mid 20th-century English, and not easily
> adapted or expanded to other languages or even to ongoing
> sound changes in English, where new vowel distinctions arise
> or old ones disappear.
>
>
